org.apache.tamaya.spi

Class FilterContext

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.tamaya.spi.FilterContext

  • public class FilterContext
extends Object
    A filter context containing all the required values for implementing filtering.
    See Also:
    PropertyFilter

    • Constructor Detail

      • FilterContext

        public FilterContext(String key,
                     Map<String,String> configEntries,
                     boolean singlePropertyScope)
        Creates a new FilterContext.
        Parameters:
        key - the key under evaluation, not null.
        singlePropertyScope - true, if the filtering is done only for one single property accessed explcitily.
        configEntries - the raw configuration data available in the current evaluation context, not null.

    • Method Detail

      • getKey

        public String getKey()
        Get the key accessed. This information is very useful to evaluate additional metadata needed to determine/ control further aspects of the conversion.
        Returns:
        the key. This may be null in case where a default value has to be converted and no unique underlying key/value configuration is present.

      • isSinglePropertyScoped

        public boolean isSinglePropertyScoped()
        Method that determines if filtering is done for a single property accessed, or as part of call to getProperties().
        Returns:
        true, if its scoped to a single property accessed.

      • getConfigEntries

        public Map<String,String> getConfigEntries()
        This map contains the following keys:
        • the original value before any filters were applied on it.
        • all values starting with an _<key>., for example a.value may have a map set with a.value (oringinal value), _a.value.origin, _a.value.type, etc. The exact contents is determine by the PropertySources active.
        Also important to know is that this map given contains all the evaluated raw entries, regardless of the filters that are later applied. This ensures that met-information required by one filter is not hidden by another filter, because of an invalid filter ordering. In other words filters may remove key/value pairs, e.g. fir security reasons, by returning null, but the values in the raw map passed as input to the filter process will not be affected by any such removal (but the final properties returned are affected, of course). Finally, when a single property is accessed, e.g. by calling Configuration.get(String).
        Returns:
        the configuration instance, or null.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
